content.processed:
Rules and recommendations

All retail is generally closed. However, the sale of the basic goods is permitted.

The government of the Czech Republic prohibits retail sales and the sale and provision of services at establishments, with the exception of the following establishments: 

  • shops selling foodstuffs, 
  • shops selling fuel and other goods required for the operation of motor vehicles,
  • facilities selling fuel,
  • shops selling hygienic goods, cosmetics and other toiletries and household products, 
  • pharmacies, dispensaries and shops selling medical devices,
  • shops selling animal feed and other supplies for animals
  • shops selling glasses, contact lenses and related goods,
  • shops selling newspapers and magazines,
  • shops selling tobacco products
  • shops selling spare parts for vehicles and production technologies,
  • establishments enabling the collection of goods and shipments purchased remotely,
  • shops selling gardening supplies, including seeds and seedlings,
  • flower shops,
  • shops selling household products and ironmongery, where household products do not include furniture, carpets and other floor coverings,

Opened stores must follow all existing hygienic and operational measures. (They are listed below).

Stores selling various goods, both permitted and unauthorised, must separate these goods so as it is not possible to buy prohibited goods.

Opening hours

Stores that can remain open will be open from 5 AM - 8PM. Stores must be closed on public and non-public holidays.

Gas stations, pharmacies and airport shops, railway stations and medical facilities are exempt from the mandatory opening hours; they do not have to comply with the regulation regarding the opening hours.

All stores that are not listed in the exceptions list must be closed. These include clothing and shoe stores, furniture and flooring stores, bookstores, jewellery and stationery.

Hygiene rules

Please follow the hygiene rules. It is necessary to wear a respirator or other protective equipment without an exhalation valve with a filtration efficiency of at least 94% (class FFP2 / KN 95) and to keep distance from other customers (especially when waiting in a queue). Before entering the shop, disinfect your hands, and repeat after returning home. For greater protection, it is recommended to wear gloves. Do not touch any surface unnecessarily and use gloves when picking fruits, vegetables or pastries. We recommend that you pay cashless. 

Shops and shopping centres can only be entered in groups of 2. The reservation of 15 square meters for one customer is mandatory for any shop or service facility. Customers must also keep a distance of 2 meters from each other. 

In establishments smaller than 15m², this restriction will not apply to persons under the age of 15 and holders of a disability card. In the case of establishments larger than 15 m², this rule will not apply to children under the age of 6 accompanying another customer.

Holders of a disability card will have a priority right to enter establishments so that they do not have to wait in queues. People with a stroller do not need to have a shopping cart, and the child in the stroller will not count towards the number of people allowed in the sales area. Sales area means the area accessible to customers, including the one under the placed stands, test booths, counters and the area behind the counters, which is used by the sellers. It does not include warehouses, offices, etc.

Service providers will ensure 2m spacing in the queues, the maximum possible air circulation with the intake of outdoor air (ventilation or air conditioning) without recirculation of air in the building.This is so that fresh air goes into the premises, which prevent customers to breathe the air which is circulation inside the store, because the coronavirus can spread in aerosols.

Promotional activities are prohibited in stores when conducted in person.   

﻿As of March 9, 2021, establishments will be obliged to disinfect frequently affected areas (door handles, shopping basket handles, payment terminals) at least twi ce a day. Applies for Pilsen Region only.

At-risk groups and people in quarantine

If you are part of a higher risk group or are in quarantine (isolation), ask a neighbour, relative or friend to do your shopping. If this isn't possible, you can reach out to volunteers, who will be happy to assist you. You can also order online and get your shopping delivered to your doorstep.

Pay attention to the new restriction adjusting the free movement of persons which is in force from March 1, 2021. Now, you need a confirmation when you cross the district borders. Learn more about the free movement of persons here.

questions_answers.question: How many people can go shopping at the same time?
questions_answers.value: The limit is 2 people, except for members of one household.

questions_answers.question: Can stores be open on Sundays?
questions_answers.value: Yes.

questions_answers.question: Can stores be open on Sundays?
questions_answers.value: Yes.

questions_answers.question: Can pensioner go shopping?
questions_answers.value: Yes, the measure reserving shopping hours for pensioners is not in force.

questions_answers.question: Can I pay in cash?
questions_answers.value: Yes. But we recommend paying cashless (by credit card).

questions_answers.question: Are shopping centres open?
questions_answers.value: Yes, but only shops with a basic sortiment (especially grocery stores, drugstores and pharmacies) can operate.

questions_answers.question: Why is Wi-Fi turned off in the shopping centre?
questions_answers.value: The aim of this measure is to limit the time people sta y in public. People often stay due to free Wi-Fi, the internet connection was ordered to be temporarily turned off.

questions_answers.question: What is the sales area and how it is calculated?
questions_answers.value: You will find the answer in the Methodology for calculating the size of the sales area of establishments up to 2,500 m² and shopping centres up to 5,000 m².

questions_answers.question: How do I go shopping when I have a coronavirus?
questions_answers.value: If you are in quarantine or isolation and you cannot go buy essential goods. You can buy them online, pay by bank transfer and have your purchase delivered. You can also kindly ask someone from your loved ones or neighbours to deliver you any good you need.

questions_answers.question: What if food delivery doesn't work in the village?
questions_answers.value: Contact your loved ones or neighbours. You can also use the help of volunteers.

questions_answers.question: What hygiene rules do I have to follow in the store?
questions_answers.value: Rules Wear Z apply. Wear a face mask, stick to spacing marks and disinfect your hands regularly. The operator must ensure the possibility of disinfection for employees and customers and regularly disinfect handles, railings, shopping carts and other frequently exposed areas.

questions_answers.question: Do I have to shop in gloves?
questions_answers.value: No. But disposable gloves (or similar hand protection) must be available in stores free of charge so that every customer can use them. It is recommended to use gloves especially when buying unpackaged products (pastries, fruits, vegetables, etc.)

questions_answers.question: Is it possible to try on clothes in a store?
questions_answers.value: Clothing stores are closed at the moment.

questions_answers.question: Can my store have a dispensing window?
questions_answers.value: Yes. It is not necessary to use delivery companies, each store can have its own dispensary. Goods can also be delivered to customers' homes.

questions_answers.question: Do I have to record sales in EET?
questions_answers.value: No. The records are suspended until the end of 2022.

questions_answers.question: Are florists open?
questions_answers.value: Yes.

questions_answers.question: Are furniture stores open?
questions_answers.value: No, shops with furniture and floors are closed (they are not considered as household items).

questions_answers.question: Are pharmacies open?
questions_answers.value: Yes, and they can be open outside the opening hours.

questions_answers.question: Are hobby markets open?
questions_answers.value: They are open only for businessman as it is essential for the performance of their job.

questions_answers.question: Are garden centres open?
questions_answers.value: Yes.

questions_answers.question: What if I need to return /claim the goods, but the store is closed due to Covid-19?
questions_answers.value: You cannot physically enter the closed store as a customer. However, your customer rights are preserved. We recommend contacting a specific seller and agreeing on a specific procedure with him.

questions_answers.question: How can I help?
questions_answers.value: You can for example be a volunteer and shop for the pensioners, or donate food to the food bank.
